subject: RE: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: This is what DevCreek (www.devcreek.com) does, and the results are often surprising. For example, we noticed that on Wednesdays the DevCreek team itself wrote
messageBody:
This is what DevCreek (www.devcreek.com) does, and the results are often surprising. For example, we noticed that on Wednesdays the DevCreek team itself wrote a quarter of the tests it wrote on other days. Turns out they were spending most of the day preparing for the weekly status meeting. Teams using DevCreek don't seem to change their behavior much on the basis of the feedback, though, which I find surprising. Perhaps the feedback isn't really all that useful, perhaps we don't have the right presentation of the information, or perhaps people just need to get used to the idea that the information is there for them.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Cédric Beust ?
Sent: Monday, June 09, 2008 11:34 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit



On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 11:09 PM, Mike Hill <mike@industriallogi <mailto:mike%40industriallogic.com> c.com> wrote:
> On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 11:57 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@google. <mailto:cbeust%40google.com> com> wrote:
>>
>> I know of organizations that commit all the test results (HTML and
>> others) to databases every day so they can run long-term statistics
>> and various other metrics over the course of time.
>
> To what end?

For example, track how the number of tests evolve over time, see how
long tests remain broken in average, how long it takes to fix them,
the ratio of new code/new tests, what areas of the product receive
more tests than others, etc...

--
Cédric
